citations.narrative:
In January and February of 2024, two red-billed hornbills were found deceased inside their enclosure due to predation.
The outdoor enclosure housing the two hornbills was constructed of rigid metal wire paneling with approximately 2” x 1”
rectangular gaps. According to the facility representatives, the first hornbill was found deceased on 1/14/24 and was
thought to be predated upon by a raccoon through the enclosure wall or celling. After the initial predation event, the facility
installed 0.5” x 0.5” wire mesh over areas where the remaining hornbill was likely to be vulnerable; however, the second
hornbill was found deceased inside the enclosure on 2/1/24 with injuries associated with predation. The facility is not
currently using this enclosure to house animals.
Failure to provide a safe primary enclosure can result in injury and/or death of the birds contained within. Housing facilities
for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird housed in them.
Housing facilities for birds must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from
entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.
To be corrected from this day (6/21/24) forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
In January and February of 2024, two red-billed hornbills were found deceased inside their enclosure due to predation. 
The outdoor enclosure housing the two hornbills was constructed of rigid metal wire paneling with approximately 2” x 1” 
rectangular gaps. According to the facility representatives, the first hornbill was found deceased on 1/14/24 and was 
thought to be predated upon by a raccoon through the enclosure wall or celling. After the initial predation event, the facility 
installed 0.5” x 0.5” wire mesh over areas where the remaining hornbill was likely to be vulnerable; however, the second 
hornbill was found deceased inside the enclosure on 2/1/24 with injuries associated with predation. The facility is not 
currently using this enclosure to house animals.  
 
Failure to provide a safe primary enclosure can result in injury and/or death of the birds contained within. Housing facilities 
for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird housed in them. 
Housing facilities for birds must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from 
entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.  
 
To be corrected from this day (6/21/24) forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
 n

species.common: CONGO AFRICAN GREY PARROT / GRAY PARROT
